ALLEGATION: On 1/12/22, youth had a suspected seizure episode in the
shower at the facility. A staff member found youth on responsive and continued to
slap youth on the face until youth was awake. Youth has a red mark on the left
cheek as a result and is traumatized by the slapping.
INVESTIGATION:
On 01/14/2022 the special investigation was initiated onsite by the assigned DHHS
specialist. Covid protocol prevented initiation by DCWL staff.
On 01/14/22 an email contact was sent to the agency director and program manager
advising of investigation and requesting appointment to meet with staff and
residents.
2

On 01/18/22 an email correspondence was received that included photographs of
Youth A immediately after incident for review.
On 01/21/22 an email correspondence was sent to the agency director rescheduling
interview of residents and staff due to conflict. Appointment rescheduled for 1/27/22.
On 01/27/22 a meeting was held at Vassar facility with the agency director and the
program manager. The DHHS specialist and Vassar Police Department officer were
also present. It was confirmed that Youth A had been at the facility for about one
month. It was confirmed that staff are trained in CPR and first aid and that staff
working directly with Youth A are aware of her medical condition. It was noted that
there are no previous concerns with Staff A as an employee. It was also confirmed
that Staff A does not work with Youth A; specifically Staff A is a team leader that is
assigned to other youth. The agency director and program manager indicated that
Staff A was not aware of the medical conditions of Youth A as limited information is
shared to ensure no violation of HIPPA. It was also confirmed that Youth A has had
other medical episodes and both staff and residents have expressed that she may
be “faking”. There are no known concerns between Youth A and Staff A.
The unit where the incident occurred was viewed. It was reported that the youth
bring a chair into the shower area to place clothing and towel on while they shower.
It was also noted that the facility does not have working cameras.
Interview of Youth A
On 01/27/22 Youth A was interviewed at Vassar facility. Youth A stated she is at the
facility due to self-harming behavior and cutting her tether off. She reports that she
has seizures due to having epilepsy. Youth A confirmed that she is prescribed
medication to treat her condition and takes it regularly. She recalls that she
medication was changed right around the time this incident occurred. Youth A also
reports that she has a brain condition which she sees a doctor for. Youth A reported
that the incident occurred during shower time, which begins about 5pm. She reports
taking the chair into the area to put her clothes and towel on while showering. She
also reported taking the chair into the shower, which is not allowed. Youth A reports
that she believes she passed out or fell asleep in the shower. She confirmed that
staff was monitoring in the hallway before the shower area and other residents were
in the dorm area. Youth A advised that when the shower is closed, staff does not
come into the shower to check on them unless there is an issue. Youth A recalls
being pulled out of the shower by staff. This is when Staff A began slapping her on
her face with an open hand. Youth A reports that her face was swollen from being
slapped and that she had a red handprint on both sides of her face. Youth A
reported that staff told her to go to the medical building, but she was fine. Youth A
said that she put her hands up to shield her face when she woke up and told Staff A
that she was awake. Youth A reported no concerns with Staff A and that she is
“over” what happened. She further stated that she believed Staff A was scared and
that is why she slapped her to try to get her awake. Youth A provided the names of
3

other staff that she thought witnessed the incident. A written statement submitted by
Youth A was also reviewed.
On 1/27/22 Staff B was interviewed at Vassar facility. Staff B confirmed that she has
been employed with the facility for five years and is currently an SST (supervisor)
and was working in the unit where Youth A was on the day of the incident. Staff B
reported that the incident occurred during shower time. She reports that Youth A
was in the shower and was told to get out because her time was up. Staff B
reported that the youth was not responding and did not turn off the shower. She was
standing in the hallway area and again asked the youth to exit the shower. She then
advised Youth A that if she did not turn off the water, that the staff would enter the
shower and do so. After not getting a response, Staff B stated she placed her hand
in the shower and turned off the water. Staff B reports that she then opened the
curtain and saw Youth A sitting in the chair with her arms crossed over her chest
and was unresponsive. Staff B indicated that youth are not suppose to have the
chair in the shower and she was not sure why it was there. Staff C, Staff D and Staff
A then came over to assist. Staff A checked the throat and inside of the mouth of
Youth A and saw nothing. Staff B reported that she went to get a towel and noticed
that Youth A was breathing. Staff A took the youth out of the shower and laid her on
the floor in the bathroom. Staff A announced that she was going to begin CPR, but
when she checked her nose found that the youth was breathing. Staff A advised
Staff C to call 911. Staff B reported that when she went to get the towel for the
youth, she noted that Staff A was standing over the youth. This is when Staff B
began slapping the youth in the face with her hands. Staff B reports that she is
unsure how many times, but would guess that the youth was slapped about 10
times. Youth A then lifted her hands to shield her face and said that she was awake.
Staff B reported that Staff A did not stop slapping the youth right away. Staff B stated
that she could hear the slaps while she was looking for a towel for the youth. Staff B
stated that it is possible that Staff A panicked and that she slapped the youth about
two additional times after the youth said that she was awake. Staff B reported that
the face of Youth A was red after the incident and she was given ice and ibuprofen.
She denied that the youth saw the nurse that night. Staff B reported that after the
incident, Staff A asked her to tell the supervisors that she was doing CPR. Staff B
denies seeing Staff A do anything similar to other residents.
On 01/27/22 Staff C was interviewed at Vassar. Staff C reported she was in the
bathroom and Youth A was in the shower. She reported that the timer went off
indicating it was time for Youth A’s shower to end. Staff C reported that Staff B told
Youth A to turn the water off on several occasions with no response. Staff C then
advised the youth at she was going to come in the shower if there was no response.
Staff C reported that since there was no response, Staff B opened the shower
curtain and saw the youth laying in the chair that she had place in the shower with
her arms crossed. It was reported that Staff B turned off the shower and noted that
the youth’s eyes were closed. Staff C reported that staff checked the youth’s mouth
and neck and found nothing and then she stepped out to call 911. Staff C stated
that Staff A then took the youth out of the shower and laid her on the floor. Staff A
4

then began smacking the youth in the face in an attempt to wake her up Staff C
reported that Staff A was using an open hand and she believed it was the left hand.
After about four times, Youth A put her hands up and said that she was awake.
Youth A then got up slowly and put her clothes on. Staff C said she was unable to
recall if Staff A continued to hit youth A after she woke up. Staff C recalls that the
youth had redness to her face and the sty near her eye was bleeding after the
incident. Youth A reported to Staff C that she was “shaken up” after the incident due
to her past trauma. Youth A was given a bag of ice and ibuprofen. Staff C
confirmed that staff trained in CPR and First Aid and they aren't trained to slap
someone if they are unresponsive.
On 1/27/22 Youth B was interviewed at Vassar. The interview was led by the
Vassar Police Department. Youth B confirmed that she was in the unit when the
incident occurred with Youth A. She reported that staff was at the door of the
bathroom calling Youth A’s name and there was no answered. Youth B stated she
could not fully see into the bathroom area. She reported hearing a noise that
sounded like a slap about four times. Youth B denied seeing which staff may have
slapped Youth A. She stated she was later advised by Youth A that she was
slapped by staff, but didn’t indicate which one.
On 1/27/22 Youth C was interviewed at Vassar. The interview was led by the Vassar
Police Department. Youth C has been placed at the facility since December. Youth
C reports that she heard staff calling the name of Youth A while she was in the
shower, but the youth was not responding. Youth C said she could see in the
bathroom hall area based on where her bed is in the unit. She reported seeing Staff
A slap Youth A one time with an open hand. She reported that she believed it to be
on the left side of Youth A’s face. Youth C denied seeing any injuries to Youth A
after the incident. Youth C also recalled that this is not the first time that Youth A
had an incident. She reported that some think that the youth is faking. She further
stated that Youth A will often roll out f her bed when she is lying in it and she is
unsure why she does this.
On 1/27/22 an interview was held with Youth D. The interview was led by Vassar
Police Department. Youth D confirmed that she was aware of the incident that
occurred with Youth A. She recalled that a bathroom check was being done and
Youth A was not responding. Youth A was sleep in the shower and staff pulled her
out. Youth D reported that her bed is near the bathroom area of the unit, so she
could see. Youth D reported that Staff A slapped Youth A about six times on both
sides of her face with an open hand. She recalls that Youth A woke up and put her
arms up. Youth D denied that Staff A continued to slap Youth A once she woke up.
Youth D reported that the face of Youth A was red from being smacked, but there
were no other injuries.
On 1/27/22 an interview was held with Staff A at Vassar. Vassar police was present
for the beginning of the interview. The officer read the Miranda rights warning to
Staff A and she declined wanting to provide a statement to the officer. Staff A has
5

been employed with the agency for 14 years. She confirmed that there is
disciplinary action documented in her file, but that she has never been suspended.
Staff A reported she was in the unit to speak with another youth and that she is not
assigned to Youth A. She stated that Staff B was in the bathroom area doing a
check on Youth A because she was not responding. She reports that Youth A was
found slumped over in a chair in the shower. Staff A stated that they were calling
the name of Youth A, but she was not responding. She reported that she got Youth
A out of the chair in the shower and placed her on the floor. Staff A stated that she
told Staff B to call 911 and that she would start CPR. Youth A continued to be
unresponsive on the floor. Staff A stated that she noticed that the youth was still
breathing and admitted to slapping her on both sides of her face in order to wake her
up. She recalled that her hand was open and she did this four to five times. She
denied slapping the youth after she woke up. When asked about force, Staff A said
that on a scale of 1 to 10 she would say it was a four or five. Staff A reported that
her intent was to get a response from the youth and not to cause her any harm.
When the youth woke up, she said that she had fallen asleep in the shower. Staff A
said that the youth was wet from being in the shower but denied that her face was
red or bleeding. Staff A denied beginning CPR as she noticed the youth was
breathing. Staff A further denied having any knowledge of Youth A’s medical
condition. Staff A reported that she is trained in CPR and First Aid annually and
confirmed she is not trained to ‘slap” as a part of the training when someone is
unresponsive. Staff A described herself as feeling scared and panicky when she
saw that the youth was not responsive. She recalled that she was just trying to help
and says that there are no issues between herself and Youth A.
The employee file of Staff A was reviewed. She was hired by the facility on
12/29/2008. She had all of her appropriate training and clearances completed. The
majority of the write ups I her file were in regard to being late or calling in without
enough notice. Staff A was suspended for one day in 2019 for involvement in an
inappropriate restraint. She was also suspended for a day in 2014 for not
completing an incident report after a youth was found with a sheet around their neck.
On 2/3/22 the Tuscola County Prosecuting Attorney advised that he did not believe
that there would be enough to charge Staff A criminally.
On 2/3/22 the DHHS specialist placed a call to the office with the Vassar Police
Department. Case details were discussed. The officer advised that the case would
be closed.
On 2/3/22 the assigned DHHS specialist had phone contact with the nurse at
Vassar. She confirmed seeing Youth A the morning after the event. She denied
having any concerns regarding Youth A during the appointment. Youth A did state
that she was smacked in the face by a staff, but she had no injuries the following
day. She said the staff hit her until she was able to open her eyes and wake up.
The nurse had no concerns but did note that Youth A had some old injuries from
self-harming episodes.
6

On 2/10/22 a dispositional phone conference was held. with CPS/MIC, JJ staff and
DCWL. The allegations and case details were discussed, and it was noted that
there were no findings as it relates to abuse and/or neglect.
On 02/23/22 the agency director was advised of preliminary findings.
Documentation reviewed for this investigation includes the following:
 Nursing note from Vassar Nurse regarding Youth
 WHS – Vassar House Policies and Procedures
 Incident reports involving Youth A during placement at Vassar House dated
1/13/22
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 (C) Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: After completion of the investigation, there was sufficient
evidence to support non-compliance with licensing rule
400.4109(C). Staff A failed to appropriately respond to an
emergency and unusual incident. Although the investigation
revealed that there was no malice or intent to harm the youth
and that the “slaps” were solely intended to assist in awaking
her, the actions may have been excessive and were not
consistent with CPR and emergency response protocol.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violations.
